awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Nanofabricated multisite opto-electrical probes for optogenetic stimulation and neuronal recording applications
awd_abstract_narration:
1263987/1263785
Li/Masmanidis


Intellectual Merit:
This proposal will advance both engineering, through innovative use of nanofabrication techniques and device assembly schemes, and neuroscience, through newly enabled lines of research in which very small groups of cells (~1 to 10) can be optogenetically manipulated and electrically recorded. In the proof-of-concept study proposed here, the probes will be incorporated into the co-PI?s behavioral experiments on the neural mechanisms of reinforcement learning in the nucleus accumbens, an important brain area in the reward processing pathway. Optogenetically tagged neurons will be activated or silenced and recorded with the optoelectrodes during an associative reward learning task, allowing their activity to be perturbed at specific epochs of learning. These experiments will help both demonstrate the operation of the probes, and provide new insight into how information about appetitive stimuli is dynamically encoded in this brain area.  The development of neural probes with unsurpassed photonic and electronic capabilities will have broad impact on how optogenetics and electrophysiology are incorporated into neuroscience experiments.

Broader impacts:
 The development of neural probes with unsurpassed photonic and electronic capabilities will have broad impact on how optogenetics and electrophysiology are incorporated into neuroscience experiments. If the development strategy proposed here is successful, the PIs will seek additional funding opportunities to mass-produce these tools at commercial device foundries. This collaborative project will provide a highly interdisciplinary environment for training of graduate students and a postdoctoral scholar. Additionally, the two PIs will use existing university programs to involve high school and undergraduate students in the research effort.The investigators also plan curriculum enhancement as a direc result of this work, and have a planned program of k-12 outreach there are numerous additional educational components, including collaboration between different institutions,a plan for device dissemination in the neuroscience community, K-12 education and outreach and inclusion of high school students in summer lab projects,undergraduate training and research opportunities, graduate training, curriculum development, and interdisciplinary exchange.

por.por_cntn:
Animal behavior is the result of choreographed patterns of brain activity. The brain is one of the most complex networks in the known universe, and is the subject of intense study. One of the longstanding challenges for neuroscientists is to understand the link between these choreographed activity patterns—in the form of firing of a myriad neurons—and behavior. In general there are two strategies for deciphering the brain’s code: while animals perform certain behavioral tasks, one can either try to measure neural activity, or manipulate neural activity in order to try to change the behavior. There has been enormous progress in the last decades on the development of technologies to address the needs of these strategies. Two such technologies which are highly complementary are electrodes for measuring electrical brain signals, and optogenetics for artificially manipulating activity with optical signals. The goal of this collaborative project was to combine the unique capabilities of each technique, by integrating electrodes and light sources on the same miniaturized device. The rationale was that by combining the ability to manipulate and measure neural activity on a large scale, this would enable a more detailed understanding of how optogenetic stimulation impacts brain activity during behavior.

The project relied on nanofabrication techniques to develop arrays of microelectrodes on thin implantable silicon substrates (“silicon microprobes”). These devices contained 256 microelectrodes. Additionally, these microprobes were combined with commercial optical fibers to allow the delivery of light for optical stimulation. Performance of the devices was evaluated in mice expressing optogenetic constructs for activating or inhibiting the activity of molecularly defined populations of neurons. These tests demonstrated that the devices enabled simultaneous measurements from dozens to hundreds, concurrently with optogenetic manipulations. The project also provided a highly multidisciplinary training opportunity for a postdoctoral scholar, who was responsible for developing and testing the technology.
